para.text: Title
Your title should tell the reader what the report is about.
Changing shopping habits
Aim
Explain what you were trying to find out.
TIP You may need more than one paragraph in each section.
To find out how shopping habits have changed since a new shopping centre (Lakeview) was built out of town.
Identify future trends.
The objective of
our survey was
to find out whether
shopping habits have changed since the building of the new out-of-town shopping centre at Lakeview, and
to identify trends
for the future.
Method
Describe in detail the research you carried out.
4 groups: town-centre residents, residents of suburbs 3 miles around town, shopkeepers in town centre, traders in new shopping centre
2 questionnaires—1 for shoppers, 1 for traders
50 homes in centre and 50 in suburbs visited. Shops in both areas visited.
Four
groups of people were targeted
: A—town-centre residents; B—residents of the suburbs up to three miles around the town centre; C—shopkeepers in the central area of town; D—traders in the new shopping centre.
The research was conducted
using two questionnaires, one for shoppers and one for traders. Researchers visited 50 homes in the central area and 50 in the suburbs as well as a cross section of shops in both locations.
Results
Give details of the results of your research.
Shoppers: 75% had been to shopping centre twice in last month, mostly from group B. Main reasons: plenty of free parking; lots of stores in one place. Families—play area an advantage.

Group A: two thirds  liked to be able to walk to shops. 8 out of 10 older people said daily shopping was only contact with people. Also preferred personal attention of smaller shops rather than impersonal large stores. However, felt prices are increasing.

Traders: Group C (town centre)—business has decreased by half. Group D (Lakeview traders)—business steadily increasing. Majority of group D positive about future. Only 5% of group C thought sales would increase in next 12 months.
Shoppers
75% of
all residents said that they had been to the new shopping centre at least twice during the last month.
Of these, the majority
were from group B (residents of the suburbs). Among
the most popular reasons cited

for visiting Lakeview in preference to the town centre were the ample free parking there compared with the difficulties of parking in the town centre and the convenience of having a large number of stores in one location in the shopping centre. Families, in particular, mentioned the Lakeview children's play area as an important advantage.
In contrast, two thirds
of those questioned in group A (town-centre residents) reported that they valued the convenience of being able to walk to the shops.
Eight out of ten of
the older shoppers surveyed said that their daily shopping trip was their only contact with other people.
Moreover
, they preferred the personal attention of the smaller shops compared with the anonymous atmosphere of the larger outlets. They were, however, concerned that prices were increasing.
Traders
Group C, the town-centre traders, have seen business drop off by up to a half, whereas Lakeview traders (Group D) have recorded a steady increase in sales over the year. When
asked whether
they viewed the future with optimism, a large majority of group D replied positively, while only 5% of group C said that they expected to see a growth in their business in the coming year.
Conclusions
Draw  conclusions from the research and results.
Lakeview has had serious effect on town centre—will probably continue.
Parking problems in centre important—mobile customers going out of town.
Centre shops only for local residents e.g. elderly and those without cars.
Many businesses facing difficulties.
The opening of the Lakeview shopping centre has clearly
had a devastating effect on
the town centre, and
this trend seems set to continue
. Parking problems in the town centre have been
a significant factor

in changing people's habits. Mobile, better-off consumers are deserting the high street for the new shopping centre, leaving the town-centre traders relying on the custom of local residents, particularly the elderly and those without cars.
As a result,
many long-established businesses now face grave difficulties.

steps.label: What is a report for?
desc: A report describes a study, an investigation or a project. Its purpose is to provide recommendations or updates, and sometimes to persuade readers to accept an idea. It is written by a single person or a group who has investigated the issue. It is read by people who require the information.

steps.label: How is the report structured?
desc: Below is the framework that was used to create this report.

steps.label: How was the report planned?
desc: In order to plan the report, the writer decides what to cover in each paragraph and takes notes.

filters.label: The writer uses key words or phrases for a report.

checkList.text: Do your research and gather all your information, including facts and figures.
Organize your notes into the framework.
Ask yourself questions about your readers.
checkList.tellMeMore:
You need to make the objective of the report clear so that people who are reading it know why they are reading. Thinking about the readers and what they need to know will help improve your report.

  • Is the purpose of the report clear throughout?
  • Can the readers find the information they need?
  • Will diagrams or tables make the information clearer?
  • Should I just present the facts or include recommendations as well?

checkList.text: Use language to state your objectives.
checkList.tellMeMore:
The purpose/aim/objective of this report is to...
This report aims to...
This report presents/gives information on...

checkList.text: Use language to outline your research and present your findings.
checkList.tellMeMore:
Outlining research
We asked (e.g. two developers) to...
We conducted our research by... (e.g. asking a group of...)
We examined/looked at/researched... (e.g. the problem/the cost/several companies)
We surveyed... (e.g. a total of 250 employees))
We compared A and B.
The group was made up of...
Presenting findings
We found that, on the whole,...
According to the majority of respondents...
Overall people preferred...
50% of those surveyed said (that)...

checkList.text: Use language to give conclusions and recommendations.
checkList.tellMeMore:
Giving Conclusions
In conclusion...
The research shows/demonstrates that...
The research shows/demonstrates + noun (e.g. the effect of...)
From the research/From the evidence we conclude that...
Giving recommendations
We recommend that...
It is recommended that...
The best solution is/would be to... (e.g. adopt design A)
The best solution is /would be + noun (e.g. a reduction in office hours)
If we do A, we will see B.
This will have an impact on + noun (e.g. costs /productivity/the business)

checkList.text: Make your report as long as necessary but as short as possible.
The main body of your report should be mainly factual and not based on opinion.
Does the title clearly show what the report is about?
Does the aim state the purpose of the report?
Does the method explain how I found out information and facts?
Are the results reported accurately and clearly?
Does the conclusion clearly give my opinion about the findings?
Have I checked vocabulary, grammar and spelling?
